sub_topic: Predicting the color of inorganic compounds
message_1: What is the predicted color of FeCl3 solution when diluted with water, and how does that color change if a few drops of NaOH solution are added?
message_2:
When FeCl3 (Iron(III) chloride) is dissolved in water, it forms a yellow-colored solution. This is due to the presence of Fe3+ ions in the solution.

When a few drops of NaOH (sodium hydroxide) solution are added to the FeCl3 solution, a reaction occurs between Fe3+ ions and OH- ions from NaOH. This reaction forms a reddish-brown precipitate of Fe(OH)3 (Iron(III) hydroxide).

Fe3+ (aq) + 3OH- (aq) â†’ Fe(OH)3 (s)

So, upon adding NaOH to the FeCl3 solution, the color changes from yellow to reddish-brown due to the formation of Fe(OH)3 precipitate.
